p: Although the initial human isolates of highly pathogenic avian A/H5N1 viruses in Hong Kong in 1997 were M2 inhibitor susceptible, resistance to this class of drugs has become more prevalent [ 32, 37]. Most clade 1 A/H5N1 viruses are resistant to the M2 inhibitors as a result of the Ser31Asn substitution, while most (~80 %) of clade 2.1 A/H5N1 are resistant secondary to Ser31Asn or Val27Ala substitution [ 32, 37]. Of note, most of the clade 2.2 and 2.3 A/H5N1 viruses remain susceptible to M2 inhibitors [ 37]. Isolates of A/H7N9 infected humans have also had the Ser31Asn mutation conferring resistance to the M2 inhibitors [ 49, 50].
